security: Releasing details of investigations into individuals, especially concerning potential field board actions, could compromise personnel security processes. The request for FBI records and assessment of objections to further processing, particularly when a field board action may result, could reveal the criteria and triggers for such actions.
summary: A memorandum from J.B. Finnegan, COL AIS, to the Director of the FBI, requesting any reports concerning Robert Scheer subsequent to a report dated 3-14-66, and inquiring whether the FBI has any objection to further processing of the case.
summary_one_paragraph: This unclassified memorandum, dated March 8, 1967, from J.B. Finnegan of the Personnel Security Division, Assistant Chief of Staff for Intelligence, Department of the Army, to the Director of the FBI, seeks updated reports on Robert Scheer (born April 4, 1936, in Bronx, New York) following a previous report from March 14, 1966. The memo also asks whether the FBI objects to further processing of Scheer's case, which could lead to a field board action, and specifies that correspondence should be routed through the FBI Liaison Representative to the Personnel Security Division.
